fields.name: Insulate your water heater
fields.content: If the outside of your water heater feels warm, heat is escaping and your system could benefit from additional insulation.

fields.name: Replace your outdated refrigerator
fields.content: An Energy Star-rated refrigerator gives your kitchen a sleek, fresh look while saving a ton of energy.

fields.name: Adjust the temperature setting on your water heater
fields.content: Lowering the temperature on your hot water heater prevents scalding and saves real energy. For every 10° you lower your water heater, you'll save around 5% on your water heating bill.American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, Consumer Guide to Home Energy Savings: Condensed Online Version, Water Heating
fields.teaser: Adjust the temperature setting on your water heater

fields.name: Have a home audit
fields.content: A home audit will give you the tools to understand and unlock the unique energy saving opportunities in your home.

fields.name: Insulate your water pipes
fields.content: Just like your water heater, adding insulation to your hot water pipes helps them stay hotter, longer. Insulated pipes deliver water that's 2ºF–4ºF hotter than uninsulated pipes, allowing you to turn your water heater down while maintaining your water heater temperature.Department of Energy, Energy Savers, Insulate Hot Water Pipes for Energy Saving Insulated pipes are also better protected against frost.

fields.name: Install a chimney draft guard
fields.content: Draft guards keep warm air where it belongs.

fields.name: Wash your clothes in cold water
fields.content: If you wash your clothes in cold water instead of hot, your washing machine will use 90% less energy per load.Planet Green, Beat the Heat, Wash in Cold
fields.teaser: Wash your clothes in cold water

fields.name: Cut standby power
fields.content: 75% of the electricity used to power home electronics and appliances is consumed while the products are turned off.Department of Energy, Appliances & Electronics This "vampire" power accounts for 5-10% of your electric bill.Lawerence Berkley National Laboratory, Standby Power: FAQs

fields.name: Use a programmable thermostat
fields.content: Your home will be more comfortable when you're there, and more efficient when you're away.

fields.name: Dial down your thermostat when you're at home
fields.content: You can save energy without sacrificing comfort.

fields.name: Seal off vents in unoccupied rooms
fields.content: Vent covers allow you to prevent unnecessary heating and cooling in hobby rooms, guest rooms, and other occasional-use spaces. Closing these vents will help your HVAC system work faster and use less energy.
fields.teaser: Seal off vents in unoccupied rooms

fields.name: Change your air conditioning and heater filters every three months
fields.content: Clean filters help your system run efficiently, last longer, and improve indoor air quality.
fields.teaser: Change your air conditioning and heater filters every three months

fields.name: Use your ceiling fan in the summer
fields.content: Fans create a more comfortable home and lower cooling bills.
fields.teaser: Use your ceiling fan in the summer

fields.name: Use motion sensors and/or timers for "always-on" lights
fields.content: You can stop wasting hours of electricity every day when you only need a few minutes.
fields.teaser: Use motion sensors and/or timers for "always-on" lights

fields.name: Keep your fireplace damper closed
fields.content: Your fireplace is supposed to keep you warm, but leaky fireplaces often make your house colder by drawing warm air up the flue.

fields.name: Install a low-flow shower head
fields.content: The energy you save by switching will power your television for a year.Installing two low-flow shower heads will save the average household 300 kWh per year: WaterSense® Draft Specification for Showerheads Supporting Statement, p. 5A 32" LCD television on for 3 hours, every day uses 139.2 kWh of electricity a year: How much electricity does my stuff use?

fields.name: Use your ceiling fan in the winter
fields.content: Your fan can be a windfall for energy savings all year long.
fields.teaser: Use your ceiling fan in the winter

fields.name: Install a low-flow sink aerator
fields.content: If every household in the United States installed low-flow faucet accessories, we could save about $600 million in annual energy costs from heating water. WaterSense Labeled Sink Faucets and Accessories

fields.name: Replace your incandescent light bulbs with CFLs
fields.content: CFLs are four times more efficient than outdated incandescent light bulbs.ToolBase Services, Compact Fluorescent Lighting Keep track of your progress with this list.
fields.teaser: Replace your incandescent light bulbs with CFLs

fields.name: Caulk around your windows
fields.content: Savvy homeowners know that small gaps make a huge difference in energy bills. Luckily there's an easy solution: caulking. Caulking can seal gaps that are up to 1/4" wide. Tubes often cost less than $8, making caulking one of the best repairs you can do yourself.

fields.name: Insulate your windows
fields.content: Heat loss from your windows accounts for 10-25% of your winter heating bill."Energy Saver Tips: Windows." Energy Savers. Department of Energy. 22 Jan 2009. 25 Jan 2010. Inexpensive insulation kits create more comfortable rooms and lower bills.

fields.name: Replace your windows
fields.content: New windows are an expensive upgrade with a longer payback period, so they probably shouldn't be first on your list. However, if you've already made other improvements, new windows can make a big difference in your your home's appearance and performance.

fields.name: Set your computer to sleep automatically
fields.content: "Screen savers" don't save any energy, but sleep mode does. By activating sleep mode, you can $25-$75 per computer annually."Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)." ENERGY STAR. n.d. 27 Jan 2010.
